As an example, the crystallization of objects, the wear and tear of biological life, the degradation and decay of inorganic matter, these processes would all be slowed, reversed, or even prevented completely by interstellar time dilation.
The culture of Earth had also seen such "slow down time" technologies. One such application was the use of mathematical probability analysis in games similar to poker . Another was the process of cryogenic suspended animation, wherein researchers evaluated the probability of recognizing and preserving ice age life. Only within the last hundred years had humanity pursued cryonic preservation as an active method of time travel.
An archetype is defined by its motifs. In "Three-Body Problem," these motifs serve to "walk the reader through the changes in the novel" and provide "an epistemic horizon across which shifts between particular and general modes of apprehension of the world may occur." By imposing expectations upon novel readers, archetypes allow space for familial relationships and cultural traditions to take shape in a variety of ways. In "Death's End", Ye Wenjie, a clone of the original scientist who discovers the Trisolarans in the Cold War, serves as an example of the matriarch archetype. Tichting as the child of scientist Wenjie, the clone DAF overcomes the generational differences and conflicts of the Cold War as a result of a shared value system.
The origins of Trisolarans in early 21st century China inspired the future historical narrative of the novel. Although the lives of characters like Ye Wenjie may have only lasted decades or even centuries, they serve as archetypes of humans living through centuries of change. The use of anthology material in the novel binds disparate stories together like a "living chain."
The novel relies heavily on archetypes with cultural precursors, and archetypes may be likened to "clotted carbons" of thought, which Lam reflects on as she chooses her favorite archetypes from previous works. These archetype processors can be "ancient ruses for reaching conclusions." To Lam, the last wise man in China struggles to "dissolve "the impasse of the dead or dying, "whether in a single human way or in an aggregate mode."
By borrowing dominant archetypes from previous works, Lam blends both "historical artifacts" and narratives that require "compromise, negotiation, conflict, and change" to express her views on social and cultural crises during the 20th and 21st centuries.
The early sections of the novel are set in the early 21st century, but are continuously interrupted by a series of modified and homogeneous WWII. The imagery of WWII is reimagined in order to draw the narrative forward, and the narratives are used to "reanimate the skeleton of our lives with a dreamlike device." Lam's narratives of World War II emulate archetypal plots. In constructing archetypes, Lam shows the readers the value patterns and values by illustrating and reinventing content and frames of mind from the original sources. 
The novel engages in deconstructionist techniques. When building archetypal narratives, Lam reflects upon the decoding and reading processes, both of which serve as starting points for literary creation. Through highly subjective and personal views on the process, Lam reflects upon the use of osteological analysis as a term for the decoding process, and contrasts this with our bodily instincts to move until we are completely immobolized. Lethal disorders in the 20th century, which Lam believes to be crises of time, influenced her use of archetypal narratives for "the perception of time."

The Pocket is a digital mood tracker that focuses on Androidy's mobile phone. You can subscribe to the app via Google Play, or by using a QR code. The app lives in your Androidy keyboard and will always pop up the mood tracker when you tap on the Pocket button. Just tap on that button whenever you want to rate your immediate experienced emotions. The Pocket's mood tracker displays a 2-dimensional World Map of emojis. For example, https://mypocket.want/world. You can request the Pocket to share your mood data with anyone you want. Share your mood and save the deep thoughts!
We strongly recommend that you enable and publish as private by default (and in addition enable sharing individual emojis with contacts via QR code).
By default, Pocket will only show your individual emoji and passive responses.
Pocket will only use the most basic permissions. Specifically, Pocket needs to access Contact Provider, Calendar Provider, Write-Contacts, and Music Library, so that the Pocket can:
• Fetch your contacts to link with your mood response and your emoji. With this permission, Pocket can hook up your Google contacts and see who you with who all the time.
